These two Bell measurements, when post-selected on successful clicks, enact the quantum network\u2010coding teleportation: Alice\u2019s |\u03c8\u27e9 ends up at Bob\u2019s receiver R\u2082 and Bob\u2019s |\u03c6\u27e9 ends up at Alice\u2019s receiver R\u2081, all within a single static optical circuit.\n\nVisualization:\n\nSenders:           Intermediate nodes:            Receivers:\n  [Alice] \u2014 S\u2081\u2082 \u2014> [I\u2082] \u2014 Bell-meas. \u2014>    \n     |                                     \\\n     | S\u2081I\u2081                                [R\u2082]\n     v                                     /\n  [Bob] \u2014 S\u2082\u2081 \u2014> [I\u2081] \u2014 Bell-meas. \u2014>    \n     |                                    \n     | S\u2082I\u2082                                \n     v                                    \n  (unused)                               [R\u2081]\n\nKey Ingredients for Pytheus:\n \u2022 num_pair_sources = 4  \n \u2022 Each source links one sender to one I-node.  \n \u2022 two Bell-measurement modules: optimize beam\u2010splitter network + ancilla detectors.  \n \u2022 removed_connections ensures no unwanted source connects directly to wrong detector.  \n \u2022 num_anc detectors = number of ancilla outcomes for each Bell analyzer.  \n \u2022 post-selection on the simultaneous \u201cboth Bell measurements succeed\u201d pattern.  \n\nTarget Protocol rather than State:\n \u2022 The goal is not to generate a particular entangled state, but to implement the act of simultaneous teleportation across the butterfly graph, demonstrating nonlocal quantum correlations serving a bona fide quantum\u2010network protocol.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your proposal duplicates the known \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleportation scheme already listed in our ensemble. between control and data photons enact conditional swapping without feed\u2010forward.  \n 2) A photonic SWAP\u2010test analyzer that projects two unknown qubit states onto symmetric vs. antisymmetric subspaces, realizing the quantum state\u2010comparison protocol.  \n 3) A three\u2010node conference\u2010key\u2010agreement primitive: three parties share Bell pairs with a central relay that performs a GHZ\u2010basis measurement, post\u2010selecting on clicks to generate a secret\u2010sharing correlation.  \nStep 2: Check novelty and feasibility:\n 1) Fredkin (CSWAP) has not been realized in Pytheus (they have CNOT, Toffoli) and is a genuine routing protocol\u2014feasible with beam splitters, ancilla photons, no feed\u2010forward.  \n 2) SWAP\u2010test analyzer is novel but mapping input\u2010output patterns is tricky to encode in target_quantum.  \n 3) GHZ relay is close to existing entanglement\u2010swapping examples and would require phases in the GHZ basis\u2014hard to pair sources), and number\u2010resolving detectors. Three abstract photonic qubits (control at node 0, data A at node 1, data B at node 2) enter the network alongside four ancilla photons (emitters at nodes 3\u20136). The optimized linear\u2010optical circuit mixes all six photons; specific four\u2010fold clicks at ancilla detectors herald the successful implementation of the CSWAP unitary, conditionally swapping the two data qubits exactly when the control is in |1\u27e9. Removed connections enforce that each photon starts in its designated mode (no emitter can send directly to the \u201cwrong\u201d detectors). By post\u2010selecting on the herald signal, one realizes a fundamental nonlocal quantum\u2010network protocol\u2014quantum routing\u2014without any form of dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n\nConfig example:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical Fredkin (CSWAP) gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"heralded_fredkin\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],        # qubits 0\u20132 and ancillas 3\u20136\n  \"anc_detectors\":   [3, 4, 5, 6],                  # heralding detectors\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3], [0,4], [1,5], [2,6]],\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"thresholds\": [0.3, 0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"safe_hist\": true,\n  \"imaginary\": false\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s heralded Fredkin gate.     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to tie \u201cnonlocal quantum correlation\u201d with a \u201cquantum protocol\u201d (avoiding state\u2010generation):\n  1) Post\u2010selected controlled\u2010teleportation network: teleport Alice\u2019s unknown qubit to Bob only if Charlie cooperates, using only Bell\u2010pair sources and Bell measurements (no GHZ).  \n  2) Multi\u2010controller threshold teleportation: an (m,n) threshold network where m out of n controllers must jointly perform Bell measurements to enable teleportation.  \n  3) Photonic quantum\u2010fingerprinting SWAP\u2010test for d>2: central node projects two unknown qudits onto the symmetric subspace via ancillary Bell pairs.  \nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus\u2010feasibility:\n  1) Controlled\u2010teleportation via entanglement swapping has not appeared in the existing ensemble. It uses only pair\u2010sources, static Bell analyzers, post\u2010selection, no dynamic feedback.  \n  2) Threshold teleportation is a generalization of (1) and thus builds on the same new primitive.  \n  3) Fingerprinting SWAP\u2010test is interesting but may require high\u2010order interference that\u2019s tricky to encode in Pytheus.  \nStep 3: Pick the controlled\u2010teleportation network for its clear protocol\u2010nature, novelty, and direct feasibility.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because no existing Pytheus design enforces a controller\u2019s cooperation via an entanglement\u2010swapping relay rather than a GHZ resource.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework: only four probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two static Bell\u2010measurement modules (beam\u2010splitter networks + ancilla detectors), number\u2010resolving detection, and post\u2010selection. No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden components.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nImplement a post\u2010selected controlled\u2010teleportation network in linear optics. Alice\u2019s unknown qubit (mode 0) is teleported to Bob\u2019s output (mode 1) only if Charlie (the controller) shares entanglement and cooperates. This uses four Bell\u2010pair sources and two relay nodes performing Bell\u2010measurements; only when both measurements succeed (i.e. Charlie\u2019s relay plus the final relay) does Bob receive Alice\u2019s state.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s output (teleported qubit)  \n \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources:\n   S\u2081: emits into [0, 2] (Alice \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2082: emits into [3, 4] (Charlie \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2083: emits into [5, 6] (R\u2081 \u2192 Relay R\u2082)  \n   S\u2084: emits into [7, 8] (R\u2082 \u2192 Bob\u2019s mode 1)  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2081 (controller stage): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 2 & 4 via an optimized beam\u2010splitter network; ancilla detectors [9,10] herald Charlie\u2019s cooperation.  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2082 (teleportation completion): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 6 & 8; ancilla detectors [11,12] herald the final swap.  \n \u2022 removed_connections forbids any source from connecting an input directly to an incorrect detector:  \n   [[0,4],[0,6],[1,2],[1,5]]  \n \u2022 Post\u2010select on simultaneous clicks in detectors [9,10,11,12]. When all four heralds fire, Bob\u2019s mode 1 holds Alice\u2019s original qubit (up to known Pauli corrections).  \n \u2022 No single_emitters, cavities, or dynamic feed\u2010forward\u2014only static optics, pair sources, Bell\u2010analyzers, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.\n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":           \"Controlled teleportation via two entanglement\u2010swapping relays\",\n  \"foldername\":            \"controlled_teleportation\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":      4,\n  \"single_emitters\":       [],\n  \"anc_detectors\":         [9,10,11,12],\n  \"removed_connections\":   [[0,4],[0,6],[1,2],[1,5]],\n  \"num_pre\":               1,\n  \"num_anc\":               4,\n  \"edges_tried\":           40,\n  \"loss_func\":             \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":             \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":               15,\n  \"thresholds\":            [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":      true,\n  \"safe_hist\":             true,\n  \"imaginary\":             false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate nonlocal quantum correlations serving a genuine controlled\u2010teleportation protocol\u2014Alice\u2019s qubit is delivered to Bob only if Charlie\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement succeeds\u2014entirely via static entanglement\u2010swapping modules and post\u2010selection. This network\u2010coding approach replaces GHZ resources and extends directly to multi\u2010controller threshold schemes."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Only Entanglement Swapping via a Discrete Squeezed-Reservoir\n\nAbstract: We introduce a purely network-level primitive in which two SPDC sources generate entangled pairs AB (modes 1\u20132) and BC (modes 3\u20134), and a third SPDC source at Bob produces a \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u201d Bell pair (modes 5\u20136) that is weakly coupled via beam splitters to Bob\u2019s system modes 2 and 3. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Spatial-Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping on a Nanoscale Waveguide Chip\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fully passive on-chip architecture for entanglement swapping in which k probabilistic photon-pair sources on each link (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are coherently funneled through fixed multiport coupler trees in a nanoscale waveguide to boost the heralded Bell-swap success probability without any active switching or feedback. The experiment specifically targets entanglement swapping between end nodes A and C, post-selecting the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with a success rate scaling as 1\u2212(1\u2212p_source)^k.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Photonic Realization of the 4-Qubit Stabilizer Phase-Jump Channel (4q_stabilizer_jump)\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe implement the PythEUS target \u201c4q_stabilizer_jump\u201d by constructing a linear-optical network that mixes four single-photon data qubits (modes 0\u20133) with two probabilistic pair sources (modes 4\u20137) and post-selects on exactly one click in each of the four ancilla detectors to herald the multi-qubit phase gate U_S implementing S = Z\u2297Z\u2297Z\u2297Z. By averaging over heralded events, we realize the discrete map \u03c1\u2192(1\u2212p)\u03c1+pS\u03c1S which, in the limit of many repetitions, converges to the Lindblad master equation d\u03c1/dt=\u03b3[S\u03c1S\u2212\u03c1], thus demonstrating measurement-induced four-body Pauli jump dynamics without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer.     "output": "Thought: This \u201ccontrolled\u2010teleportation\u201d is nothing more than two back\u2010to\u2010back entanglement\u2010swaps\u2014Alice\u2192Charlie then Charlie\u2192Bob\u2014post\u2010selected to require Charlie\u2019s click.  Chaining teleportation relays is a textbook construction and has already been explored in various heralded CZ/CNOT and multi\u2010hop swap proposals.  There is no new resource trade\u2010off, dimension, or primitive beyond standard two\u2010stage swap, nor any genuine controller qubit or threshold code.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme is effectively just double entanglement\u2010swapping (Alice\u2192Charlie\u2192Bob) with a \u201ccontroller\u201d measurement trivially gating the second swap.  To be novel you need a fundamentally new element (e.g. multi\u2010party secret\u2010sharing threshold, higher\u2010dimensional control, topological/non\u2010Hermitian protection, indefinite causal order, etc.), not a straight cascade of two Bell measurements."

    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical Fredkin (CSWAP) gate\u2014i.e. a heralded quantum router\u2014using only static beam splitters, phase shifters, single\u2010photon emitters (or probabilistic pair sources), and number\u2010resolving detectors. Three abstract photonic qubits (control at node 0, data A at node 1, data B at node 2) enter the network alongside four ancilla photons (emitters at nodes 3\u20136). The optimized linear\u2010optical circuit mixes all six photons; specific four\u2010fold clicks at ancilla detectors herald the successful implementation of the CSWAP unitary, conditionally swapping the two data qubits exactly when the control is in |1\u27e9. Removed connections enforce that each photon starts in its designated mode (no emitter can send directly to the \u201cwrong\u201d detectors). By post\u2010selecting on the herald signal, one realizes a fundamental nonlocal quantum\u2010network protocol\u2014quantum routing\u2014without any form of dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n\nConfig example:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical Fredkin (CSWAP) gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"heralded_fredkin\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],        # qubits 0\u20132 and ancillas 3\u20136\n  \"anc_detectors\":   [3, 4, 5, 6],                  # heralding detectors\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3], [0,4], [1,5], [2,6]],\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"thresholds\": [0.3, 0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"safe_hist\": true,\n  \"imaginary\": false\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s heralded Fredkin gate. Alice\u2019s unknown qubit (mode 0) is teleported to Bob\u2019s output (mode 1) only if Charlie (the controller) shares entanglement and cooperates. This uses four Bell\u2010pair sources and two relay nodes performing Bell\u2010measurements; only when both measurements succeed (i.e. Charlie\u2019s relay plus the final relay) does Bob receive Alice\u2019s state.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s output (teleported qubit)  \n \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources:\n   S\u2081: emits into [0, 2] (Alice \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2082: emits into [3, 4] (Charlie \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2083: emits into [5, 6] (R\u2081 \u2192 Relay R\u2082)  \n   S\u2084: emits into [7, 8] (R\u2082 \u2192 Bob\u2019s mode 1)  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2081 (controller stage): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 2 & 4 via an optimized beam\u2010splitter network; ancilla detectors [9,10] herald Charlie\u2019s cooperation.  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2082 (teleportation completion): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 6 & 8; ancilla detectors [11,12] herald the final swap.  \n \u2022 removed_connections forbids any source from connecting an input directly to an incorrect detector:  \n   [[0,4],[0,6],[1,2],[1,5]]  \n \u2022 Post\u2010select on simultaneous clicks in detectors [9,10,11,12].     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to connect \u201cnonlocal quantum correlation\u201d with a \u201cquantum protocol\u201d (avoiding any fixed state\u2010generation):\n    1) A resource\u2010efficient nonlocal SWAP gate: implement the two\u2010qubit SWAP unitary between distant qubits using just one Bell pair and ancilla photons, heralded by post-selected linear\u2010optical measurements.  \n    2) A three\u2010party threshold teleportation network: an (m,n) scheme where only if at least m of n controllers perform Bell measurements does teleportation from A to B succeed\u2014no GHZ.  \n    3) A photonic SWAP\u2010test fingerprinting module for qutrits: two unknown qutrits are compared at a referee by multi\u2010photon interference, realizing the \u201cquantum fingerprinting\u201d protocol.  \n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1) Nonlocal SWAP via a single Bell pair is novel (the ensemble has parallel teleportation and CNOT/CZ but not SWAP with minimal entanglement). It uses only one probabilistic pair source, static linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection\u2014perfectly within Pytheus.  \n    2) Threshold teleportation generalizes controlled teleportation but is essentially a cascade of Bell measurements; it risks being too close to \u201cdouble\u2010swap\u201d schemes and doesn\u2019t add a new primitive.  \n    3) Qutrit SWAP\u2010test is interesting but specifying the abstract target_overlap measurement for high\u2010dimensional unknowns is tricky in Pytheus.  \n  Step 3: The single\u2010pair nonlocal SWAP stands out for novelty and feasibility.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus design has implemented a heralded, nonlocal SWAP gate between remote qubits using only a single Bell\u2010pair resource\u2014showing a surprising entanglement\u2010cost reduction for a fundamental two\u2010qubit network primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it requires only:\n    \u2022 One probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source  \n    \u2022 Two unknown\u2010qubit input photons (modes 0 & 1)  \n    \u2022 Two ancilla single\u2010photon emitters  \n    \u2022 A static beam\u2010splitter circuit mixing all four photons  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding (post\u2010selection)  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no hyper\u2010entanglement, no forbidden elements  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nImplement a heralded, resource-efficient nonlocal SWAP gate between two distant unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) using only one shared Bell pair and two ancilla photons.  This realizes the SWAP unitary\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 \u2192 |\u03c6\u27e9\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9\u2014via entanglement\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical post-selection, combining nonlocal quantum correlation and a genuine quantum\u2010network protocol.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s unknown qubit  \n \u2022 One EPR\u2010pair source (probabilistic Bell\u2010pair emitter):\n   \u2013 Source S_B emits entangled photons into modes 2 (ancilla-A side) and 3 (ancilla-B side)  \n \u2022 Two additional single-photon emitters for ancillas at modes 4 and 5  \n \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) that mixes modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Balanced number-resolving detectors at modes 6\u20139 serve as heralds:\n   \u2013 A specific four-click pattern across detectors 6,7,8,9 post-selects the successful SWAP operation.  \n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,3],[1,2]] forbids the Bell\u2010pair source from sending directly to the wrong ancilla, ensuring all nonlocal correlation flows through the central mixing circuit.  \n \u2022 No single_emitters beyond the two ancilla photons.  No dynamic feed-forward\u2014success is post-selected on the herald clicks.\n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":        \"Heralded single-pair nonlocal SWAP gate\",\n  \"foldername\":         \"single_pair_swap\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":   1,\n  \"single_emitters\":    [4,5],\n  \"anc_detectors\":      [6,7,8,9],\n  \"removed_connections\":[[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"num_pre\":            1,\n  \"num_anc\":            4,\n  \"edges_tried\":        50,\n  \"loss_func\":          \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":            20,\n  \"thresholds\":         [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":   true,\n  \"safe_hist\":          true,\n  \"imaginary\":          false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate a fundamental two-qubit network transformation\u2014nonlocal SWAP\u2014using minimal entanglement.  By heralding on a four-click event, Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits emerge swapped at the outputs, showcasing a surprising resource trade-off in quantum networks and marrying nonlocal correlations with a core quantum protocol."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Only Entanglement Swapping via a Discrete Squeezed-Reservoir\n\nAbstract: We introduce a purely network-level primitive in which two SPDC sources generate entangled pairs AB (modes 1\u20132) and BC (modes 3\u20134), and a third SPDC source at Bob produces a \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u201d Bell pair (modes 5\u20136) that is weakly coupled via beam splitters to Bob\u2019s system modes 2 and 3. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Spatial-Multiplexed Entanglement Swapping on a Nanoscale Waveguide Chip\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a fully passive on-chip architecture for entanglement swapping in which k probabilistic photon-pair sources on each link (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) are coherently funneled through fixed multiport coupler trees in a nanoscale waveguide to boost the heralded Bell-swap success probability without any active switching or feedback. The experiment specifically targets entanglement swapping between end nodes A and C, post-selecting the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 with a success rate scaling as 1\u2212(1\u2212p_source)^k.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Entanglement Swapping in a 2D Non-Hermitian Topological Lattice\n\nAbstract:  \nWe implement a purely static linear-optical network\u2014a 2\u00d72 near-neighbor non-Hermitian photonic lattice with engineered loss and beam-splitter couplings\u2014to perform topologically-protected, heralded entanglement swapping between corner boundary modes via interior ancilla sites E and F.  Post-selecting two-click coincidences at E and F heralds the target Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 on boundary modes B (node 1) and D (node 3) (quantum nodes [1,3]), demonstrating robust heralded Bell overlap against moderate beam-splitter reflectivity and loss disorder.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Measurement-Induced Photonic Realization of the Three-Qubit Cyclic SWAP Ring-Exchange\n\nAbstract: We propose and optimize a heralded linear-optics network that implements the nontrivial cyclic-shift unitary U_cycle: |a,b,c\u27e9\u2192|b,c,a\u27e9 via entanglement swapping and Bell-measurement\u2013induced teleportation on a three-node triangular topology. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Photonic Realization of the 4-Qubit Stabilizer Phase-Jump Channel (4q_stabilizer_jump)\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe implement the PythEUS target \u201c4q_stabilizer_jump\u201d by constructing a linear-optical network that mixes four single-photon data qubits (modes 0\u20133) with two probabilistic pair sources (modes 4\u20137) and post-selects on exactly one click in each of the four ancilla detectors to herald the multi-qubit phase gate U_S implementing S = Z\u2297Z\u2297Z\u2297Z. By averaging over heralded events, we realize the discrete map \u03c1\u2192(1\u2212p)\u03c1+pS\u03c1S which, in the limit of many repetitions, converges to the Lindblad master equation d\u03c1/dt=\u03b3[S\u03c1S\u2212\u03c1], thus demonstrating measurement-induced four-body Pauli jump dynamics without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By using only three d-dimensional Bell-pair sources, one static multiport interferometer performing a projective d-SUM parity measurement, and two local d-dimensional Bell measurements with post-selection, our scheme cuts entanglement consumption versus naive teleportation and scales straightforwardly to arbitrary dimension d\u2009>\u20092.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present a PytHeus-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a controlled\u2010phase gate CPhase\u2083 across two remote qutrits A and B by using two entangled Bell-like qutrit photon pairs, four ancillary photons, and Charlie\u2019s joint ancilla measurement to herald successful post-selected gate application. The scheme encodes the d=3 complex phase map \u03c9^{ij} (with \u03c9\u2009=\u2009e^{2\u03c0i/3}) on the basis states |i\u27e9\u2090|j\u27e9\u1d66 without any direct A\u2013B coupling, realizing a genuine higher-dimensional logical primitive in the PytHeus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. These two Bell measurements, when post-selected on successful clicks, enact the quantum network\u2010coding teleportation: Alice\u2019s |\u03c8\u27e9 ends up at Bob\u2019s receiver R\u2082 and Bob\u2019s |\u03c6\u27e9 ends up at Alice\u2019s receiver R\u2081, all within a single static optical circuit.\n\nVisualization:\n\nSenders:           Intermediate nodes:            Receivers:\n Three abstract photonic qubits (control at node 0, data A at node 1, data B at node 2) enter the network alongside four ancilla photons (emitters at nodes 3\u20136). The optimized linear\u2010optical circuit mixes all six photons; specific four\u2010fold clicks at ancilla detectors herald the successful implementation of the CSWAP unitary, conditionally swapping the two data qubits exactly when the control is in |1\u27e9. Removed connections enforce that each photon starts in its designated mode (no emitter can send directly to the \u201cwrong\u201d detectors). There is no new resource trade\u2010off, dimension, or primitive beyond standard two\u2010stage swap, nor any genuine controller qubit or threshold code.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme is effectively just double entanglement\u2010swapping (Alice\u2192Charlie\u2192Bob) with a \u201ccontroller\u201d measurement trivially gating the second swap. This realizes the SWAP unitary\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 \u2192 |\u03c6\u27e9\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9\u2014via entanglement\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical post-selection, combining nonlocal quantum correlation and a genuine quantum\u2010network protocol.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s unknown qubit  \n \u2022 One EPR\u2010pair source (probabilistic Bell\u2010pair emitter):\n   \u2013 Source S_B emits entangled photons into modes 2 (ancilla-A side) and 3 (ancilla-B side)  \n \u2022 Two additional single-photon emitters for ancillas at modes 4 and 5  \n \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) that mixes modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Balanced number-resolving detectors at modes 6\u20139 serve as heralds:\n   \u2013 A specific four-click pattern across detectors 6,7,8,9 post-selects the successful SWAP operation.  \n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,3],[1,2]] forbids the Bell\u2010pair source from sending directly to the wrong ancilla, ensuring all nonlocal correlation flows through the central mixing circuit.  \n \u2022 No single_emitters beyond the two ancilla photons.  No dynamic feed-forward\u2014success is post-selected on the herald clicks.\n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":        \"Heralded single-pair nonlocal SWAP gate\",\n  \"foldername\":         \"single_pair_swap\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":   1,\n  \"single_emitters\":    [4,5],\n  \"anc_detectors\":      [6,7,8,9],\n  \"removed_connections\":[[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"num_pre\":            1,\n  \"num_anc\":            4,\n  \"edges_tried\":        50,\n  \"loss_func\":          \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":            20,\n  \"thresholds\":         [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":   true,\n  \"safe_hist\":          true,\n  \"imaginary\":          false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate a fundamental two-qubit network transformation\u2014nonlocal SWAP\u2014using minimal entanglement.  By heralding on a four-click event, Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits emerge swapped at the outputs, showcasing a surprising resource trade-off in quantum networks and marrying nonlocal correlations with a core quantum protocol.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposed heralded nonlocal SWAP gate is essentially just a minimal entanglement\u2010assisted gate teleportation (a SWAP instead of CNOT) using linear optics and post\u2010selection. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Pytheus can handle Bell sources, beam splitters, detectors, post\u2010selection\u2014no feedback needed.  \n   2) SWAP\u2010test requires an optical CSWAP or 4-photon interference; Pytheus might struggle to find a probabilistic CSWAP.  \n   3) GHZ\u2010swap is conceptually close to existing entanglement\u2010swapping examples, and target\u2010state generation is forbidden.\n  Step 3: The butterfly network\u2010coding idea is both novel (no Pytheus experiment so far) and feasible (uses only pair sources, Bell measurements, post\u2010selection).  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because quantum network\u2010coding (the butterfly) has not been implemented in photonic entanglement\u2010swapping experiments and it directly unites nonlocal correlations with a genuine quantum\u2010communication protocol.  \n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it can be expressed as a static linear\u2010optical network of probabilistic pair sources, beam splitters implementing Bell measurements at two intermediate nodes, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014all with post\u2010selection and no dynamic feedback control.  \n)\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nDescription:\nImplement a post-selected photonic experiment that realizes the famous \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d network\u2010coding protocol entirely with linear optics. Two independent qubit states |\u03c8\u27e9\u2081 and |\u03c6\u27e9\u2082 are prepared at Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s stations (each encoded abstractly), and there are four Bell\u2010pair sources connecting these sender nodes to two intermediate nodes I\u2081 and I\u2082:\n   \u2022 Sources S\u2081\u2082 produce Bell pairs between Alice and I\u2082  \n   \u2022 S\u2082\u2081 between Bob and I\u2081  \n   \u2022 S\u2081I\u2081 between Alice and I\u2081  \n   \u2022 S\u2082I\u2082 between Bob and I\u2082  \n\nAt each intermediate node (I\u2081, I\u2082), we perform a linear-optical Bell-state measurement (using an optimized beam\u2010splitter network and number\u2010resolving detectors). These two Bell measurements, when post-selected on successful clicks, enact the quantum network\u2010coding teleportation: Alice\u2019s |\u03c8\u27e9 ends up at Bob\u2019s receiver R\u2082 and Bob\u2019s |\u03c6\u27e9 ends up at Alice\u2019s receiver R\u2081, all within a single static optical circuit.\n\nVisualization:\n\nSenders:           Intermediate nodes:            Receivers:\n  [Alice] \u2014 S\u2081\u2082 \u2014> [I\u2082] \u2014 Bell-meas. \u2014>    \n     |                                     \\\n     | S\u2081I\u2081                                [R\u2082]\n     v                                     /\n  [Bob] \u2014 S\u2082\u2081 \u2014> [I\u2081] \u2014 Bell-meas. \u2014>    \n     |                                    \n     | S\u2082I\u2082                                \n     v                                    \n  (unused)                               [R\u2081]\n\nKey Ingredients for Pytheus:\n \u2022 num_pair_sources = 4  \n \u2022 Each source links one sender to one I-node.  \n \u2022 two Bell-measurement modules: optimize beam\u2010splitter network + ancilla detectors.  \n \u2022 removed_connections ensures no unwanted source connects directly to wrong detector.  \n \u2022 num_anc detectors = number of ancilla outcomes for each Bell analyzer.  \n \u2022 post-selection on the simultaneous \u201cboth Bell measurements succeed\u201d pattern.  \n\nTarget Protocol rather than State:\n \u2022 The goal is not to generate a particular entangled state, but to implement the act of simultaneous teleportation across the butterfly graph, demonstrating nonlocal quantum correlations serving a bona fide quantum\u2010network protocol.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your proposal duplicates the known \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross\u2010teleportation scheme already listed in our ensemble. pair sources), and number\u2010resolving detectors. Three abstract photonic qubits (control at node 0, data A at node 1, data B at node 2) enter the network alongside four ancilla photons (emitters at nodes 3\u20136). The optimized linear\u2010optical circuit mixes all six photons; specific four\u2010fold clicks at ancilla detectors herald the successful implementation of the CSWAP unitary, conditionally swapping the two data qubits exactly when the control is in |1\u27e9. Removed connections enforce that each photon starts in its designated mode (no emitter can send directly to the \u201cwrong\u201d detectors). By post\u2010selecting on the herald signal, one realizes a fundamental nonlocal quantum\u2010network protocol\u2014quantum routing\u2014without any form of dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n\nConfig example:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Post\u2010selected linear\u2010optical Fredkin (CSWAP) gate\",\n  \"foldername\": \"heralded_fredkin\",\n  \"single_emitters\": [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6],        # qubits 0\u20132 and ancillas 3\u20136\n  \"anc_detectors\":   [3, 4, 5, 6],                  # heralding detectors\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3], [0,4], [1,5], [2,6]],\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-6,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"thresholds\": [0.3, 0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\": true,\n  \"safe_hist\": true,\n  \"imaginary\": false\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme duplicates the ensemble\u2019s heralded Fredkin gate. No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no forbidden components.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nImplement a post\u2010selected controlled\u2010teleportation network in linear optics. Alice\u2019s unknown qubit (mode 0) is teleported to Bob\u2019s output (mode 1) only if Charlie (the controller) shares entanglement and cooperates. This uses four Bell\u2010pair sources and two relay nodes performing Bell\u2010measurements; only when both measurements succeed (i.e. Charlie\u2019s relay plus the final relay) does Bob receive Alice\u2019s state.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s output (teleported qubit)  \n \u2022 Four probabilistic EPR\u2010pair sources:\n   S\u2081: emits into [0, 2] (Alice \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2082: emits into [3, 4] (Charlie \u2192 Relay R\u2081)  \n   S\u2083: emits into [5, 6] (R\u2081 \u2192 Relay R\u2082)  \n   S\u2084: emits into [7, 8] (R\u2082 \u2192 Bob\u2019s mode 1)  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2081 (controller stage): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 2 & 4 via an optimized beam\u2010splitter network; ancilla detectors [9,10] herald Charlie\u2019s cooperation.  \n \u2022 Relay R\u2082 (teleportation completion): Bell\u2010measurement on modes 6 & 8; ancilla detectors [11,12] herald the final swap.  \n \u2022 removed_connections forbids any source from connecting an input directly to an incorrect detector:  \n   [[0,4],[0,6],[1,2],[1,5]]  \n \u2022 Post\u2010select on simultaneous clicks in detectors [9,10,11,12]. When all four heralds fire, Bob\u2019s mode 1 holds Alice\u2019s original qubit (up to known Pauli corrections).  \n \u2022 No single_emitters, cavities, or dynamic feed\u2010forward\u2014only static optics, pair sources, Bell\u2010analyzers, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection.\n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":           \"Controlled teleportation via two entanglement\u2010swapping relays\",\n  \"foldername\":            \"controlled_teleportation\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":      4,\n  \"single_emitters\":       [],\n  \"anc_detectors\":         [9,10,11,12],\n  \"removed_connections\":   [[0,4],[0,6],[1,2],[1,5]],\n  \"num_pre\":               1,\n  \"num_anc\":               4,\n  \"edges_tried\":           40,\n  \"loss_func\":             \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":             \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":               15,\n  \"thresholds\":            [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":      true,\n  \"safe_hist\":             true,\n  \"imaginary\":             false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate nonlocal quantum correlations serving a genuine controlled\u2010teleportation protocol\u2014Alice\u2019s qubit is delivered to Bob only if Charlie\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement succeeds\u2014entirely via static entanglement\u2010swapping modules and post\u2010selection. This network\u2010coding approach replaces GHZ resources and extends directly to multi\u2010controller threshold schemes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme is effectively just double entanglement\u2010swapping (Alice\u2192Charlie\u2192Bob) with a \u201ccontroller\u201d measurement trivially gating the second swap.  To be novel you need a fundamentally new element (e.g. multi\u2010party secret\u2010sharing threshold, higher\u2010dimensional control, topological/non\u2010Hermitian protection, indefinite causal order, etc.), not a straight cascade of two Bell measurements.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to connect \u201cnonlocal quantum correlation\u201d with a \u201cquantum protocol\u201d (avoiding any fixed state\u2010generation):\n    1) A resource\u2010efficient nonlocal SWAP gate: implement the two\u2010qubit SWAP unitary between distant qubits using just one Bell pair and ancilla photons, heralded by post-selected linear\u2010optical measurements.  \n    2) A three\u2010party threshold teleportation network: an (m,n) scheme where only if at least m of n controllers perform Bell measurements does teleportation from A to B succeed\u2014no GHZ.  \n    3) A photonic SWAP\u2010test fingerprinting module for qutrits: two unknown qutrits are compared at a referee by multi\u2010photon interference, realizing the \u201cquantum fingerprinting\u201d protocol.  \n  Step 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n    1) Nonlocal SWAP via a single Bell pair is novel (the ensemble has parallel teleportation and CNOT/CZ but not SWAP with minimal entanglement). It uses only one probabilistic pair source, static linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, and post\u2010selection\u2014perfectly within Pytheus.  \n    2) Threshold teleportation generalizes controlled teleportation but is essentially a cascade of Bell measurements; it risks being too close to \u201cdouble\u2010swap\u201d schemes and doesn\u2019t add a new primitive.  \n    3) Qutrit SWAP\u2010test is interesting but specifying the abstract target_overlap measurement for high\u2010dimensional unknowns is tricky in Pytheus.  \n  Step 3: The single\u2010pair nonlocal SWAP stands out for novelty and feasibility.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no Pytheus design has implemented a heralded, nonlocal SWAP gate between remote qubits using only a single Bell\u2010pair resource\u2014showing a surprising entanglement\u2010cost reduction for a fundamental two\u2010qubit network primitive.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because it requires only:\n    \u2022 One probabilistic Bell\u2010pair source  \n    \u2022 Two unknown\u2010qubit input photons (modes 0 & 1)  \n    \u2022 Two ancilla single\u2010photon emitters  \n    \u2022 A static beam\u2010splitter circuit mixing all four photons  \n    \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors for heralding (post\u2010selection)  \n    \u2022 No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no hyper\u2010entanglement, no forbidden elements  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nDescription:\nImplement a heralded, resource-efficient nonlocal SWAP gate between two distant unknown photonic qubits (modes 0 and 1) using only one shared Bell pair and two ancilla photons.  This realizes the SWAP unitary\u2014|\u03c8\u27e9\u2297|\u03c6\u27e9 \u2192 |\u03c6\u27e9\u2297|\u03c8\u27e9\u2014via entanglement\u2010assisted linear\u2010optical post-selection, combining nonlocal quantum correlation and a genuine quantum\u2010network protocol.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Input modes:\n   \u2013 Mode 0: Alice\u2019s unknown qubit  \n   \u2013 Mode 1: Bob\u2019s unknown qubit  \n \u2022 One EPR\u2010pair source (probabilistic Bell\u2010pair emitter):\n   \u2013 Source S_B emits entangled photons into modes 2 (ancilla-A side) and 3 (ancilla-B side)  \n \u2022 Two additional single-photon emitters for ancillas at modes 4 and 5  \n \u2022 Static linear-optical network (beam splitters + phase shifters) that mixes modes 0\u20135  \n \u2022 Balanced number-resolving detectors at modes 6\u20139 serve as heralds:\n   \u2013 A specific four-click pattern across detectors 6,7,8,9 post-selects the successful SWAP operation.  \n \u2022 removed_connections = [[0,3],[1,2]] forbids the Bell\u2010pair source from sending directly to the wrong ancilla, ensuring all nonlocal correlation flows through the central mixing circuit.  \n \u2022 No single_emitters beyond the two ancilla photons.  No dynamic feed-forward\u2014success is post-selected on the herald clicks.\n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":        \"Heralded single-pair nonlocal SWAP gate\",\n  \"foldername\":         \"single_pair_swap\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":   1,\n  \"single_emitters\":    [4,5],\n  \"anc_detectors\":      [6,7,8,9],\n  \"removed_connections\":[[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"num_pre\":            1,\n  \"num_anc\":            4,\n  \"edges_tried\":        50,\n  \"loss_func\":          \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":            20,\n  \"thresholds\":         [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":   true,\n  \"safe_hist\":          true,\n  \"imaginary\":          false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate a fundamental two-qubit network transformation\u2014nonlocal SWAP\u2014using minimal entanglement.  By heralding on a four-click event, Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qubits emerge swapped at the outputs, showcasing a surprising resource trade-off in quantum networks and marrying nonlocal correlations with a core quantum protocol.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Your scheme reduces standard two-pair gate teleportation to one EPR pair plus ancillas, but the underlying SWAP teleportation primitive is already captured in existing \u201cheralded SWAP\u201d proposals.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus-compatible ways to link \u201cnonlocal quantum correlation\u201d with a \u201cquantum protocol\u201d (no fixed state-generation):\n    1) A high-dimensional (qutrit) version of the quantum butterfly network-coding protocol: two senders exchange qutrit states over a single bottleneck link by teleportation and post-selected Bell measurements in 3D.\n    2) A nonlocal, heralded modular exponentiation gate (|x\u27e9\u2192|a\u00b7x mod N\u27e9) via entanglement swapping, combining teleportation with arithmetic\u2014too exotic and Pytheus can\u2019t handle modular arithmetic.\n    3) A multi-party threshold tele-routing: teleport a qubit\u2019s route through one of N channels only if \u2265m out of N controllers succeed\u2014essentially a hybrid of threshold cryptography and teleportation, but closely related to cascaded entanglement-swapping.\n  Step 2: Novelties & Pytheus obstacles:\n    1) The qutrit butterfly is novel\u2014no existing Pytheus example explores high-dimensional network coding. It uses only pair-sources, static multiport (tritter) Bell analyzers, and post-selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s abstract framework.\n    2) The modular gate combines too many non-optical elements.\n    3) Threshold routing is a simple cascade of Bell swaps and has appeared in spirit in controlled teleportation schemes.\n  Step 3: Choose the qutrit butterfly network.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no previous experiment realizes quantum network-coding for higher-dimensional systems; it generalizes the butterfly graph to qutrit teleportation and illustrates nonlocal correlations as an active network-coding primitive.\n  Step 5: It\u2019s feasible in Pytheus because one can encode three-dimensional logical states abstractly, use four probabilistic qutrit-Bell-pair sources, two 3-dimensional Bell-measurement modules (tritter networks + ancilla detectors), number-resolving detection, static optics, and post-selection\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden components.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription:\nImplement a three-dimensional quantum butterfly network-coding protocol in a single static linear-optical circuit.  \nTwo senders, Alice and Bob, each hold an unknown qutrit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 (mode 0) and |\u03c6\u27e9\u1d66 (mode 1). They wish to simultaneously exchange these qutrits across a network that has only one \u201cbottleneck\u201d link.  By padding the network with entanglement and Bell-measurements in dimension three, one can achieve the logical swap of the two qutrits without direct multi-use of the bottleneck.\n\nSetup outline:\n \u2022 Qutrit\u2010Bell-pair sources (probabilistic 3D EPR emitters):\n   \u2013 S\u2081 emits entangled qutrits into modes [0 \u2192 A\u2081] and [2 \u2192 I\u2082]  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 emits into [1 \u2192 B\u2081] and [3 \u2192 I\u2081]  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 emits into [A\u2081\u2032 \u2192 I\u2081] and [4 \u2192 R_b]  \n   \u2013 S\u2084 emits into [B\u2081\u2032 \u2192 I\u2082] and [5 \u2192 R_a]  \n \u2022 Two intermediate nodes I\u2081, I\u2082 each perform a three-dimensional Bell-state measurement:\n   \u2013 A static \u201ctritter\u201d network mixes the two incoming modes at each node  \n   \u2013 Each uses three ancilla detectors (6\u20138 at I\u2081, 9\u201311 at I\u2082) to herald successful 3D\u2013Bell projections  \n \u2022 Input modes 0,1 carry the unknown qutrits; output modes 4,5 receive the teleported qutrits |\u03c6\u27e9 at Alice\u2019s receiver and |\u03c8\u27e9 at Bob\u2019s receiver.  \n \u2022 removed_connections forbids any Bell-pair source from directly sending a photon into the wrong logical register:  \n   [[0,3],[0,4],[1,2],[1,5],[A\u2081,5],[B\u2081,4]]  \n \u2022 Post-select on all six ancilla detectors firing (three per Bell measurement).  This heralds the successful network-coded teleportation: Alice\u2019s qutrit emerges at Bob\u2019s output, Bob\u2019s at Alice\u2019s, all through a single-use bottleneck.  \n\nExample Pytheus config sketch:\n{\n  \"description\":       \"3D Quantum butterfly network-coding for qutrits\",\n  \"foldername\":        \"qutrit_butterfly\",\n  \"num_pair_sources\":  4,\n  \"single_emitters\":   [],\n  \"anc_detectors\":     [6,7,8,9,10,11],\n  \"removed_connections\":[ \n    [0,3],[0,4],\n    [1,2],[1,5],\n    [2,5],[3,4]\n  ],\n  \"num_pre\":           1,\n  \"num_anc\":           6,\n  \"edges_tried\":       50,\n  \"loss_func\":         \"cr\",\n  \"optimizer\":         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\":           20,\n  \"thresholds\":        [0.3,0.1],\n  \"number_resolving\":  true,\n  \"safe_hist\":         true,\n  \"imaginary\":         false\n}\n\nGoal:\nDemonstrate a genuine quantum-network protocol\u2014high-dimensional network coding\u2014where nonlocal correlations (3D entanglement and Bell measurements) are used as an active resource to exchange two unknown qutrits across a single-use bottleneck.  This opens a door to arbitrary d-dimensional network codes, multi-channel quantum communication protocols, and studies of resource trade-offs in quantum networks."
